body:
>I think it could be better to keep all of the meaningful user-focussed documentation in the public methods, and the private methods can contain very light documentation notes for developers (if absolutely necessary), or be undocumented (comments where they are called in the public methods can explain what they are being used for if needed).

Hm, I don't like that - I think even abstracts and privates should be well-documented in-place, i.e., directly in the code.
More docstrings do not necessarily mean more readability, but in this case (and more often than not) I think it does - as the base classes would be a common place for advanced users to look for an explanation of how sktime works internally.

Hi @fkiraly, yes I agree, the forecasting API needs to be simplified, this is still mostly my first attempt. 

I'm not sure what the best solution is in terms of base classes. Many implementations at the moment are in fact interfaces to other packages. I agree that the use of `_predict` saves us from some code duplication but makes it hard to understand and extend.

In hindsight, I'd also remove the `update_predict` functionality from the estimator class and implement in a separate stand-alone function. It adds a lot of complications inside the class for handling state changes.

High-level, I see two major options - both resulting in a merge of the two base class templates:
* make it more lean and adopt the pattern where `fit`, `predict`, etc are overridden in concrete implementation descendants
* make it nested (but consistent) and have `fit` and `_fit` and `predict` and `_predict`, where utility functionality and other plumbing sits in the public methods, while extenders consistently implement the private ones

An "outsider" option but perhaps more elegant is to do the first, and mimick behaviour of the second via decorators on the methods.

>In hindsight, I'd also remove the update_predict functionality from the estimator class and implement in a separate stand-alone function. It adds a lot of complications inside the class for handling state changes.

Regarding `update_predict`: I'd advocate to leave it in, because it's a very common deployment mode that users might expect and actually use (I suspect without concrete evidence but from my view of the field - opinions anyone?).
We just need to very carefully think about the state model here.

In deployment, you'd use `update` and `predict` separately or what we call `update_predict_single` - of course they need to stag. 

But `update_predict` does temporal CV which creates lots of complications - I don't see any reasons why that should live in the class but open to other thoughts?

issue.body:
From my comments in #420:

I think we very much need to write up template designs, type conventions, extension conventions. This information is typically not suitably covered by an auto-generated API reference, as it is distributed across classes - the generic template, and the conventions implemented in the concrete desendants. Sth like in sklearn dev guidelines could work, but I'd actually prefer to also have "formal" template definitions collected in one place. While the typing makes things clearer, it also makes the necessity to document the interface cleanly greater.

Opinions, @mloning, @TonyBagnall?

I'm not sure what the "final form" should be here, but I feel this needs to be manually written and curated, with any modification to template patterns and conventions.
Could live on the wiki, linked from user docs, or directly in the official docs.

Happy to contribute to this, but let's discuss first where it should live.

issue.title: Forecast base class refactor and extension template

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This PR is addressing the forecaster base class proliferation discussed in #510, by simplifying the base class inheritance tree and the streamlining the private method logic.

Specifically, I've moved the logic from `_SktimeForecaster` and the forecasting horizin mixins into `BaseForecaster`, and adopted uniformly the principle of having a public method (`fit`, `predict`, etc) with checks/plumbing, dispatching to a "core logic" version (`_fit`, `_predict`, etc) where validated arguments can be assumed.

The burden on extenders becomes much lighter, since it is now possible to only focus on the "core logic" implementation, instead of having to keep in mind a myriad of inconsistent and constantly shifting conventions in checks and other plumbing.

As side effects, if we get this right, this should make a few things on the roadmap easier:
* the extension guidelines #464. Right now, the aforementioned implicit conventions are too many and intricate to write useful extension guidelines, in my opinion.
* extending to the multivariate case
* input/output checks and the eternal data container discussion, this can go in the plumbing

As a proof-of-concept regarding ease of extension, this PR also contains a highly annotated extension template in the `extension_templates` folder.

In terms of review, the key file is `forecasting/base/_base`, with corresponding changes (contraction and deletion) in `base/_sktime`.

I've tried to keep the interface consistent as much as possible (only changing internal logic).

Interface contracts with all the earlier estimators are still honoured, via loopthroughs and default behaviour that ensures that everything still works if `fit`, `predict` etc are overridden by the current descendants, as opposed to `_fit` and `_predict`.
The only change I had to made to descendants is set `self._is_fitted=False` at the start of `fit`, which is a minimally invasive change that's also separately reviewable as PR #941.

There should only be a single change that breaks the tagging/inspection interface, which is replacing the choice of which forecasting horizon mixin one inherits from with a choice of the new `fh_in_fit` tag (can be `'requried'` or `'optional'`).
Temporarily, I've left both mixins and the `_SktimeForecaster` in and handled their behaviour as expected (inheriting from a mixin sets the `fh_in_fit` tag), so existing classes should still run, unless there is interface inconsistency or bugs in my refactor. Mid-term, we may want to remove the fh-mixins and `_SktimeForecaster` in favour of a single `BaseForecaster` class.

issue.title: Refactor checking of forecasting horizon (_set_fh)

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Reference issues/PR
Conditional on #955 
Related to #510 

#### Suggested changes
I've thought about this a bit more and I prefer the option where we pass the name of the calling method to `_set_fh` in the `BaseForecaster`, e.g. `_set_fh(fh, method="fit")`. For me, the main reasons are:
* it keeps the functionality for checking/setting the fh contained to that function and does not assume state changes elsewhere in the code, like at the beginning of fit,
* it keeps it closer to the implementation of other estimator types where we do not re-set the state at the beginning of fit,
* it avoids the redundancy of having to set _is_fitted=False in the constructor and at the beginning of fit.

issue.title: [ENH] investigate use of abc for base classes, write STEP

labels.name: implementing framework
labels.description: Implementing frameworks for new learning tasks

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
@TonyBagnall recently suggested to use of abc for classifiers in *#1873, #1708), and this was also previously discussed a number of times: #1424, #1708, #510, #420.

I do think we need to work out a STEP for this, it would be a major change to the interface framework.

There are some open questions that I have:
* which classes would inherit from `ABCMeta`?
* how do we deal with optional abstract methods?
* how does this integrate with the tag system in `BaseObject`? This could be updated using `ChainMap`.
* are there any problematic interactions of the public/private nesting pattern `fit`/`_fit`?
* we would still like to have capability tags that tell us whether an optional method is implemented or not, e.g., `predict_proba` or `predict_interval`. How would this interact with `abc`?
* how would downwards compatibility and deprecation work here?
* what about polymorphic estimators, e.g., a pipeline that can act like a transformer or a forecaster? Would `abc` not complain about missing transformer methods if it happens to behave like a forecaster and vice versa?

There's probably more once we have a proper design discussion, this is only off the top of my head.
